comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Again.  Lady in centre in white is, I think, Delia Larkin. On her left is possibly Hanna Sheehy Skeffington and it may be Louie Bennett on her right. In the second row, second from right may be Constance Marckievicz.  Hanna Sheehy's Skeffington's husband, Francis Sheehy Skeffington was shot on Mount Street Bridge in 1916 for no valid reason. This is the third picture showing Delia Larkin and another Library picture also shows her with Hanna Sheehy Skeffington and the lady who may be Louie Bennett.  Don't know if that is yet in Flickr

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: If it is Constance Markievicz on second row, second from right, then the lady first on right is surely her sister, Eva Gore Booth.  Eva suffered from ill health after her early years of beauty and this picture shows it.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69587809@N05] Have just replaced photo with higher quality one. Hope that helps...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69587809@N05] Not sure that on Delia's left is Hanna Sheehy-Skeffington. This is Hanna, pictured 2-3 years after this photo was taken: multitext.ucc.ie/viewgallery/354 Can't find any clear early photos (definitely) of Louie Bennett to compare against. Also not convinced (sorry!) about Constance Markievicz. Here's an array of photos of Constance, many from our NLI collections: multitext.ucc.ie/viewgallery/1331
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content:
Many thanks. The picture of Hanna Sheehy Skeffington in your link is from 1916. She looks broken, as her husband had been shot dead.  There is a picture on the cover of her biography not unlike that in the NLI group picture.

The two ladies in second row look to be sisters.  The fourth on right column and the second facing in left column of your link are not unlike the lady in the NLI picture which I had thought was Constance Markievicz. From the beginning photographers staged pictures. These women were with others going through a grim period. They were asked to look grim.  At any rate I'm glad Delia Larkin is identified and think the others will be in time.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: The workers aren't wearing badges, but the five ladies under discussion are. This suggests  they are leaders of the Suffragist and Revival Movement in Ireland, particularly in Dublin, at that time.  I think that whenever they are identified it will be found that they are from that noble group.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69587809@N05] I'd agree. By and large, they look better dressed too... And Delia Larkin was only identified thanks to you!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Given today's announcement it might be interesting to re-open this one (or other similar shots) to identify some of the other people in the photo. I suggest this because, even the campaigners to name the bridge after Rosie Hackett seem unsure of whether/which lady she might be in these photos. (There are photos in her later years, but no apparent confirmed ones contemporary to the IWWU foundation, lockout, etc). In this one we undoubtedly see Delia Larkin seated/front/centre. And it seems likely that Rosie Hackett, Kathleen Lynn, and other founder members are also in these photos. But where? (Similar "searches" are ongoing elsewhere too - with pretty limited success). Worth reopening?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Great suggestion! Happy to go along with it... Here's a photo of Rosie in old age. We're looking for a small and feisty lady!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Good stuff. Thanks. As you note, every description I've read suggests she was a small lady (bird-like was a term used), so maybe someone (perhaps someone trained in facial recognition of passport photos/etc) could help. And, to be honest, it's not just about Rosie Hackett. Seems unfair that history only seems to remember 1 of the 30+ people in this photo :\

comment.author: 45520926@N08
comment._content: Here area a few more of Rosie Hackett might be of use: www.flickr.com/photos/45520926@N08/9670253429/ www.flickr.com/photos/45520926@N08/9670250447/ www.flickr.com/photos/45520926@N08/9670233485/

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I think I may have identified Winifred Carney & Kathleen Clarke above - can't be absolutely certain though.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] That's great. I am more convinced on Kathleen Clarke than Winnie Carney, but I recon you might be right on both. (Again though am not sure we could ever be certain).

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/45520926@N08] Thanks for those. We knew we were looking for a lady who was of smaller stature, but those photos put that into more context. (Exactly the same context in fact as it allows us to directly compare environment). I wonder whether Rosie is standing behind (with hand on shoulder of) the seated lady that ccferrie labelled as Kathleen Clarke.

(The more I look at these images the more I wonder whether, without contemporary photos that have already been verified, we'll ever have more than speculation on this.)
